title: Cat. 26  Salver, 1748/53
publication_title: American Silver in the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Elias Boudinot (American, 1706–1770)  
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania  
Silver; 4.2 × 33.7 × 31 cm (1 5/8 × 13 3/8 × 12 3/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, Albert Pick, Jr., Fund, 1977.48

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Elias Boudinot was born in New York, the son and grandson of Huguenot immigrants who fled France at the time of the revocation of the Edict of Nantes, which deprived French Protestants of their religious and civil rights. In 1722 Boudinot was apprenticed to Huguenot silversmith Simeon Soumaine while maintaining close ties to another Huguenot silversmith, Peter Vergereau, who married Boudinot’s elder sister, Susannah. After completing his apprenticeship in 1729, Boudinot moved to Antigua, where he managed family business interests. In 1734 Boudinot relocated to Philadelphia, establishing himself as a silversmith. His first shop was located next door to Benjamin Franklin’s printing shop and post office on Market Street; he subsequently moved to Second Street. Franklin may have been responsible for Boudinot’s appointment in 1752–53 as postmaster in Princeton, New Jersey, where Boudinot also established himself as a merchant and tavern keeper but continued to work as a silversmith. His most productive years as a craftsman were the 1740s and early 1750s, when he made silver for prominent Philadelphia patrons, including tankards for Franklin and his wife, Deborah, and George and Anna (Clarke) O’Kill. He fashioned a teapot for jurist and landowner John Stockton and his wife, Abigail, of Princeton, whose son Richard married Boudinot’s daughter Annis in 1758. Suffering from ill health, Boudinot left Princeton by May 1762 and then lived in Elizabethtown, New Jersey, with his son, lawyer Elias Boudinot, who later served as one of New Jersey’s delegates to the Second Continental Congress. In a letter of December 11, 1762, to the younger Boudinot, Franklin writes, “I hope your good father’s indisposition will be of no long continuance.” In Elizabethtown Boudinot continued working as a silversmith, fabricating a few objects that can be documented to the years prior to his death, including a mug for his granddaughter Suzanne made about 1765.

Boudinot’s salver bears close resemblance to London models from the second quarter of the eighteenth century featuring S- (or cyma-) curve borders with shells and scrolled feet with acanthus leaves. Its original owners were Henry Harrison (1714–1766) and his wife, Mary Aspden (1719–1803), of Philadelphia, who married in 1748. The Harrisons presumably acquired the item while Boudinot resided in the city; their house on Coombs Alley (now Cuthbert Street) was located two blocks north of Boudinot’s Second Street shop. Harrison was a wealthy dry-goods merchant and served as mayor of Philadelphia in 1762–63; his estate was estimated to be worth £15,086.12.0, including 157 troy ounces of plate valued at £78. 10.o (0ver $2 million in today’s terms). The salver apparently descended to the Harrisons’ son George (1762–1845), who in 1792 married Sophia Francis (1769–1851); their initials form the monogram GSH, engraved on the front. In addition, a second salver marked by Boudinot, identical to the Art Institute’s in dimensions, weight, and cast elements, was made for the Philadelphia merchant John Wallace and his wife, Mary Maddox, who married in 1750 (see fig. 26.1).  
David L. Barquist

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry2" id="curatorial_entry2">Twice on top (fig. 26.2)

Engraved on top in a cipher: GSH

Engraved on bottom in Roman capitals: H/HM (fig. 26.3)

Engraved on bottom in script: ILMM (fig. 26.4)

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Henry Harrison (1714–1766; mayor of Philadelphia, 1762–63) and Mary Aspden Harrison (1719–1803; m. 1748), Philadelphia, c. 1748.

Probably by descent to George Harrison (1762–1845) and his wife, Sophia Francis (1769–1851; m. 1792).

By descent to their great-niece Mary Harrison White (1805–1875), wife of Reverend James Montgomery, D.D. (1787–1834; m. c. 1825).

With Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Pike Graves, both b. Newburyport, MA.

By descent to their daughter, Mrs. Samuel Cabot (Nancy Graves), by 1956.

With Firestone and Parson, Boston, by 1977.

Sold to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1977.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">Boston, Museum of Fine Arts, Colonial Silversmiths: Masters and Apprentices, November 14–December 30, 1956, cat. 272.

Philadelphia Museum of Art, Exhibition of Philadelphia Silver, 1682–1800, April. 14–May 27, 1956, cat. 40 (as “Tray,” lent by Mrs. Samuel Cabot).

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Biographical information on Boudinot comes from Backlin-Landman (1968); Robertson (1980).

J. Brown (1982).

Labaree (1966), p. 174.

Van Hoesen (1973), p. 111.

Hackenbroch (1969), cat. 165; Wees (1997), cats. 325, 331.

Linn and Egle (1878–80), vol. 8, p. 10. Antiquarian and genealogist Carl M. Williams first proposed the Harrisons as the original owners, based on his research in Philadelphia city records. Carl M. Williams to Milo M. Naeve, August 11, 1978, curatorial files, Department of American Art, Art Institute of Chicago. Williams’s conclusion is borne out by the sets of initials subsequently engraved on the salver.

“Inventory of the Estate of Henry Harrison decd,” February 6, 1773, Philadelphia Probate Records, Philadelphia City Archives, City Hall, Philadelphia. For monetary conversion, see Eric Nye, “Pounds Sterling to Dollars: Historical Conversion of Currency,” http://www.uwyo.edu/numimage/currency.htm.

For George and Sophia (Francis) Harrison, see Bolton (1900), p. 57; Will Book 4, p. 40, Probate Records, Philadelphia City Archives. The monogram ILMM engraved on the underside suggests that the salver may have descended from George and Sophia Harrison to their great-niece Mary Harrison White (1805–1875), granddaughter and namesake of George’s sister Mary (Harrison) White (1750–1797), who married Bishop William White (1748–1836) in 1773. The younger Mary White married the Reverend James Montgomery (1787–1834) around 1825; J. White (1879).

Philadelphia Museum of Art (2005-68-7).
